metadata.synopsis: After marrying the charming and seductive Sir Thomas Sharpe, young Edith (Mia Wasikowska) finds herself swept away to his remote gothic mansion in the English hills. Also living there is Lady Lucille, Thomas' alluring sister and protector of her family's dark secrets. Able to communicate with the dead, Edith tries to decipher the mystery behind the ghostly visions that haunt her new home. As she comes closer to the truth, Edith may learn that true monsters are made of flesh and blood.

reviews: It's been quite some time since I saw a film, especially a horror film, that I wouldn't change one thing about it.
The set designs are simply phenomenal.

While the love/hate relationship audiences had with CRIMSON PEAK delivered a middling worldwide box office for the film, I contend that not only is it one of the best haunted house movies of all time but ranks as Guillermo Del Toro's true masterpiece.
Sure, Del Toro's usual flair for grotesque visuals is apparent, though these spiritual permutations sometimes feel too over-the-top for a narrative that justifies a YA range of intellect.
I felt like I was on a ride with a storyteller who knew exactly what he was doing.
A melodramatic gothic romance mystery that's as unusual and compelling as that sounds.
Crimson Peak is a fantastic gothic romance that's filled with plenty of mystery, punctuated with several bumps in the night.
A spectacle that does not hold any surprises and that fails in its ability to keep in suspense. [Full Review in Spanish]
If Merchant-Ivory made a horror film it would look something like this.

There's nothing else like it out right now, and if you've got an inner Goth or English major, this will be right up your alley. It's utterly unique, and could only have been made by Guillermo del Toro.
There are so many holes in [the] story, I just don't think it's salvageable.
Overall, Crimson Peak is gorgeous to look at, but is ultimately let down by its half-baked plot.
Crimson Peak is visually stunning and offers sophisticated performances but the tragic story won't be remembered for its content as much as its presentation.
The greatness and failure of Crimson Peak as a film are altogether at war with each other.
The master of magic has created something wonderful to look at but emotionally null and void.
Thoroughly engaging, del Toro delivers a stylistically classy film that is sure to please.

Each of the actors handles the drama with aplomb, and they sell the fright with vigor - especially Chastain, who gives a stirring performance as a grave woman whose grating demeanor suggests a cat with ready claws.
I unapologetically LOVE Crimson Peak for everything that it is ... yes, even Charlie Hunnam as Edith's sad-eyed, shafted suitor. Incredible, I know.
Nothing, however, could distract from the stunningly detailed gothic imagery which, like in many del Toro pictures, supersedes everything else.
It's all a little over the top, at times, but that's all part of the fun and del Toro sustains the interest throughout.
